snippet: The government has settled on 99 weeks as the appropriate duration for unemployment insurance, but there's plenty of room for political compromise between maintaining this duration and terminating benefits entirely, an economist writes.
abstract: The government has settled on 99 weeks as the appropriate duration for unemployment insurance, but there's plenty of room for political compromise between maintaining this duration and terminating benefits entirely, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline.main: With Unemployment Insurance, Is 99 Weeks the Magic Number?
